        Email display settings<h2>Email display settings</h2>

        There is a setting<a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.<p>There is a <a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.</p>

        Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.<p>Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.</p>

        If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to get
        involved<a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.<p>If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to <a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.</p>


        
          
      
        <slot></slot>
      <button>
        <slot></slot>
      </button>
    
            Got it
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      <chops-dialog id="privacyDialog" forced="">
        <h2>Email display settings</h2>

        <p>There is a <a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.</p>

        <p>Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.</p>

        <p>If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to <a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.</p>


        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      </chops-dialog>

      
      
        
          <slot></slot>
        <div class="dialog-content">
          <slot></slot>
        </div>
      <dialog class="dialog" role="dialog">
        <div class="dialog-content">
          <slot></slot>
        </div>
      </dialog>
    
        This site hosts public issues in public projects<h2>This site hosts public issues in public projects</h2>

        Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.<p>Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.</p>

        Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.<p>Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.</p>

        

        
          
      
        <slot></slot>
      <button>
        <slot></slot>
      </button>
    
            Got it
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      <chops-dialog id="corpModeDialog" forced="">
        <h2>This site hosts public issues in public projects</h2>

        <p>Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.</p>

        <p>Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.</p>

        

        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>

      VERSION<b class="line"><!---->VERSION<!----></b><br><br>Chrome Version: 105<span class="line"><!---->Chrome Version: 105<!----></span><br>Operating System: Ubuntu 20.04<span class="line"><!---->Operating System: Ubuntu 20.04<!----></span><br><br>VULNERABILITY DETAILS<b class="line"><!---->VULNERABILITY DETAILS<!----></b><br><br>It gets an unknown crash with READ of size 8 when first accessing the chrome://gpu URL with a chrome extension<span class="line"><!---->It gets an unknown crash with READ of size 8 when first accessing the chrome://gpu URL with a chrome extension<!----></span><br><br>REPRODUCTION CASE<b class="line"><!---->REPRODUCTION CASE<!----></b><br><br>== background.js<span class="line"><!---->== background.js<!----></span><br><br>chrome.windows.create({ url: 'about:blank' }, (win) => {<span class="line"><!---->chrome.windows.create({ url: 'about:blank' }, (win) =&gt; {<!----></span><br>    chrome.tabs.update(win.tabs[0].id, { url: 'chrome://gpu' });<span class="line"><!---->    chrome.tabs.update(win.tabs[0].id, { url: 'chrome://gpu' });<!----></span><br>});<span class="line"><!---->});<!----></span><br><br>It seems to consistently crash the GPU process on any first navigation to chrome://gpu<span class="line"><!---->It seems to consistently crash the GPU process on any first navigation to chrome://gpu<!----></span><br>I think it's just a weird thing with WebGPU. I can repro on Canary and Dev which have WebGPU enabled on my machine, but can't repro on Beta which has WebGPU disabled by default<span class="line"><!---->I think it's just a weird thing with WebGPU. I can repro on Canary and Dev which have WebGPU enabled on my machine, but can't repro on Beta which has WebGPU disabled by default<!----></span><br><br>REQUEST FOR CC:<span class="line"><!---->REQUEST FOR CC:<!----></span><br><br>Please CC <span class="line"><!---->Please CC <!----></span>alesandro@alesandroortiz.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="/u/alesandro@alesandroortiz.com"><!---->alesandro@alesandroortiz.com<!----></a> here in this report if this report go forward. He's mentoring me.<span class="line"><!----> here in this report if this report go forward. He's mentoring me.<!----></span><br><br>CREDIT INFORMATION<b class="line"><!---->CREDIT INFORMATION<!----></b><br><br>Vitor Torres <<span class="line"><!---->Vitor Torres &lt;<!----></span>https://github.com/vtorres/<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://github.com/vtorres/"><!---->https://github.com/vtorres/<!----></a>><span class="line"><!---->&gt;<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Thanks for the report!<span class="line"><!---->Thanks for the report!<!----></span><br><br>It'd help us a lot if you could attach all of the files needed for the reproduction (i.e. the extension manifest, etc.). It'd also help a lot if you could work on providing a *symbolized* stack trace.<span class="line"><!---->It'd help us a lot if you could attach all of the files needed for the reproduction (i.e. the extension manifest, etc.). It'd also help a lot if you could work on providing a *symbolized* stack trace.<!----></span><br><br>I can't reproduce this without the extension, and if that's all the extension is doing, I'd be pretty surprised if this impacted real users. Extensions have extremely limited capabilities on chrome:// URLs (including an inability to open them at all).<span class="line"><!---->I can't reproduce this without the extension, and if that's all the extension is doing, I'd be pretty surprised if this impacted real users. Extensions have extremely limited capabilities on chrome:// URLs (including an inability to open them at all).<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        On my Windows machine (Windows 10 Version 21H2 (Build 19044.2006)) , this repros on ASan build 1058972 + 108.0.5355.0 Dev + 109.0.5364.0 Canary, but doesn't repro on 107.0.5304.36 Beta nor 106.0.5249.119 Stable.<span class="line"><!---->On my Windows machine (Windows 10 Version 21H2 (Build 19044.2006)) , this repros on ASan build 1058972 + 108.0.5355.0 Dev + 109.0.5364.0 Canary, but doesn't repro on 107.0.5304.36 Beta nor 106.0.5249.119 Stable.<!----></span><br><br>I'm able to reproduce this on Windows simply by going to chrome://gpu after loading a fresh browser instance, but only get the following from ASan:<span class="line"><!---->I'm able to reproduce this on Windows simply by going to chrome://gpu after loading a fresh browser instance, but only get the following from ASan:<!----></span><br>[7584:10084:1017/194641.304:ERROR:gpu_process_host.cc(990)] GPU process exited unexpectedly: exit_code=1<span class="line"><!---->[7584:10084:1017/194641.304:ERROR:gpu_process_host.cc(990)] GPU process exited unexpectedly: exit_code=1<!----></span><br><br>When this occurs, the Chrome window is mostly black as well for a few seconds (typical of a GPU process crash).<span class="line"><!---->When this occurs, the Chrome window is mostly black as well for a few seconds (typical of a GPU process crash).<!----></span><br><br>If you try navigating to chrome://gpu after a repro, it won't repro until you restart the browser instance again.<span class="line"><!---->If you try navigating to chrome://gpu after a repro, it won't repro until you restart the browser instance again.<!----></span><br><br>I'm actually not certain if this is related to WebGPU, because now my Canary instance shows WebGPU as disabled but it still repros there. (A couple of days there seemed to be a correlation between WebGPU being enabled and the crash.)<span class="line"><!---->I'm actually not certain if this is related to WebGPU, because now my Canary instance shows WebGPU as disabled but it still repros there. (A couple of days there seemed to be a correlation between WebGPU being enabled and the crash.)<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        It can be triggered by an extension (or anything else) opening chrome://gpu for the first time since browser was opened, so only apparent prerequisites are installing a malicious extension and that chrome://gpu hasn't been opened since browser was opened (it's very likely this is met or could be met in the near future since extensions can try again when browser is restarted).<span class="line"><!---->It can be triggered by an extension (or anything else) opening chrome://gpu for the first time since browser was opened, so only apparent prerequisites are installing a malicious extension and that chrome://gpu hasn't been opened since browser was opened (it's very likely this is met or could be met in the near future since extensions can try again when browser is restarted).<!----></span><br><br>Since it's still being analyzed, there's a chance this is only a stability issue, right? Or is it confirmed to be a security issue?<span class="line"><!---->Since it's still being analyzed, there's a chance this is only a stability issue, right? Or is it confirmed to be a security issue?<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>
      </div>
    
      
    <mr-comment headinglevel="2"></mr-comment>

          Labels:<strong><!---->Labels:</strong>

      <div class="issue-diff">
        <!---->
          <strong><!---->Labels:</strong>
          
          -reward-topanel reward-0

        Thank you for this report and your efforts, Vitor and Alesandro. In evaluating this issue, we don't see any demonstrable evidence of the OOB read. The fix itself is purely a functional fix and we aren't able to see how this is could be exploited. If you can provide some sort of evidence demonstrating the OOB memory access, such as a symbolized stack trace, we would be happy to reassess, but for now we are unable to extend a reward for this report.<span class="line"><!---->Thank you for this report and your efforts, Vitor and Alesandro. In evaluating this issue, we don't see any demonstrable evidence of the OOB read. The fix itself is purely a functional fix and we aren't able to see how this is could be exploited. If you can provide some sort of evidence demonstrating the OOB memory access, such as a symbolized stack trace, we would be happy to reassess, but for now we are unable to extend a reward for this report.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        1. Open asan with --enable-unsafe-webgpu flag<span class="line"><!---->1. Open asan with --enable-unsafe-webgpu flag<!----></span><br>2. Visit any link inside it <span class="line"><!---->2. Visit any link inside it <!----></span>https://austin-eng.com/webgpu-samples/samples/<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://austin-eng.com/webgpu-samples/samples/"><!---->https://austin-eng.com/webgpu-samples/samples/<!----></a><br>3.       VERSION<b class="line"><!---->VERSION<!----></b><br><br>Chrome Version: 105<span class="line"><!---->Chrome Version: 105<!----></span><br>Operating System: Ubuntu 20.04<span class="line"><!---->Operating System: Ubuntu 20.04<!----></span><br><br>VULNERABILITY DETAILS<b class="line"><!---->VULNERABILITY DETAILS<!----></b><br><br>It gets an unknown crash with READ of size 8 when first accessing the chrome://gpu URL with a chrome extension<span class="line"><!---->It gets an unknown crash with READ of size 8 when first accessing the chrome://gpu URL with a chrome extension<!----></span><br><br>REPRODUCTION CASE<b class="line"><!---->REPRODUCTION CASE<!----></b><br><br>== background.js<span class="line"><!---->== background.js<!----></span><br><br>chrome.windows.create({ url: 'about:blank' }, (win) => {<span class="line"><!---->chrome.windows.create({ url: 'about:blank' }, (win) =&gt; {<!----></span><br>    chrome.tabs.update(win.tabs[0].id, { url: 'chrome://gpu' });<span class="line"><!---->    chrome.tabs.update(win.tabs[0].id, { url: 'chrome://gpu' });<!----></span><br>});<span class="line"><!---->});<!----></span><br><br>It seems to consistently crash the GPU process on any first navigation to chrome://gpu<span class="line"><!---->It seems to consistently crash the GPU process on any first navigation to chrome://gpu<!----></span><br>I think it's just a weird thing with WebGPU. I can repro on Canary and Dev which have WebGPU enabled on my machine, but can't repro on Beta which has WebGPU disabled by default<span class="line"><!---->I think it's just a weird thing with WebGPU. I can repro on Canary and Dev which have WebGPU enabled on my machine, but can't repro on Beta which has WebGPU disabled by default<!----></span><br><br>REQUEST FOR CC:<span class="line"><!---->REQUEST FOR CC:<!----></span><br><br>Please CC <span class="line"><!---->Please CC <!----></span>alesandro@alesandroortiz.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="/u/alesandro@alesandroortiz.com"><!---->alesandro@alesandroortiz.com<!----></a> here in this report if this report go forward. He's mentoring me.<span class="line"><!----> here in this report if this report go forward. He's mentoring me.<!----></span><br><br>CREDIT INFORMATION<b class="line"><!---->CREDIT INFORMATION<!----></b><br><br>Vitor Torres <<span class="line"><!---->Vitor Torres &lt;<!----></span>https://github.com/vtorres/<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://github.com/vtorres/"><!---->https://github.com/vtorres/<!----></a>><span class="line"><!---->&gt;<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Thanks for the report!<span class="line"><!---->Thanks for the report!<!----></span><br><br>It'd help us a lot if you could attach all of the files needed for the reproduction (i.e. the extension manifest, etc.). It'd also help a lot if you could work on providing a *symbolized* stack trace.<span class="line"><!---->It'd help us a lot if you could attach all of the files needed for the reproduction (i.e. the extension manifest, etc.). It'd also help a lot if you could work on providing a *symbolized* stack trace.<!----></span><br><br>I can't reproduce this without the extension, and if that's all the extension is doing, I'd be pretty surprised if this impacted real users. Extensions have extremely limited capabilities on chrome:// URLs (including an inability to open them at all).<span class="line"><!---->I can't reproduce this without the extension, and if that's all the extension is doing, I'd be pretty surprised if this impacted real users. Extensions have extremely limited capabilities on chrome:// URLs (including an inability to open them at all).<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        On my Windows machine (Windows 10 Version 21H2 (Build 19044.2006)) , this repros on ASan build 1058972 + 108.0.5355.0 Dev + 109.0.5364.0 Canary, but doesn't repro on 107.0.5304.36 Beta nor 106.0.5249.119 Stable.<span class="line"><!---->On my Windows machine (Windows 10 Version 21H2 (Build 19044.2006)) , this repros on ASan build 1058972 + 108.0.5355.0 Dev + 109.0.5364.0 Canary, but doesn't repro on 107.0.5304.36 Beta nor 106.0.5249.119 Stable.<!----></span><br><br>I'm able to reproduce this on Windows simply by going to chrome://gpu after loading a fresh browser instance, but only get the following from ASan:<span class="line"><!---->I'm able to reproduce this on Windows simply by going to chrome://gpu after loading a fresh browser instance, but only get the following from ASan:<!----></span><br>[7584:10084:1017/194641.304:ERROR:gpu_process_host.cc(990)] GPU process exited unexpectedly: exit_code=1<span class="line"><!---->[7584:10084:1017/194641.304:ERROR:gpu_process_host.cc(990)] GPU process exited unexpectedly: exit_code=1<!----></span><br><br>When this occurs, the Chrome window is mostly black as well for a few seconds (typical of a GPU process crash).<span class="line"><!---->When this occurs, the Chrome window is mostly black as well for a few seconds (typical of a GPU process crash).<!----></span><br><br>If you try navigating to chrome://gpu after a repro, it won't repro until you restart the browser instance again.<span class="line"><!---->If you try navigating to chrome://gpu after a repro, it won't repro until you restart the browser instance again.<!----></span><br><br>I'm actually not certain if this is related to WebGPU, because now my Canary instance shows WebGPU as disabled but it still repros there. (A couple of days there seemed to be a correlation between WebGPU being enabled and the crash.)<span class="line"><!---->I'm actually not certain if this is related to WebGPU, because now my Canary instance shows WebGPU as disabled but it still repros there. (A couple of days there seemed to be a correlation between WebGPU being enabled and the crash.)<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        It can be triggered by an extension (or anything else) opening chrome://gpu for the first time since browser was opened, so only apparent prerequisites are installing a malicious extension and that chrome://gpu hasn't been opened since browser was opened (it's very likely this is met or could be met in the near future since extensions can try again when browser is restarted).<span class="line"><!---->It can be triggered by an extension (or anything else) opening chrome://gpu for the first time since browser was opened, so only apparent prerequisites are installing a malicious extension and that chrome://gpu hasn't been opened since browser was opened (it's very likely this is met or could be met in the near future since extensions can try again when browser is restarted).<!----></span><br><br>Since it's still being analyzed, there's a chance this is only a stability issue, right? Or is it confirmed to be a security issue?<span class="line"><!---->Since it's still being analyzed, there's a chance this is only a stability issue, right? Or is it confirmed to be a security issue?<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

is a macro for __builtin_unreachable()<span class="line"><!---->UNREACHABLE is a macro for __builtin_unreachable()<!----></span><br>hard to say exactly what is happening without looking at the assembly, but it could be that the compiler assumes it'll never reach this code, so it doesn't even emit the code to return from the function.<span class="line"><!---->hard to say exactly what is happening without looking at the assembly, but it could be that the compiler assumes it'll never reach this code, so it doesn't even emit the code to return from the function.<!----></span><br>And so what happens instead is that when running code, the process will just go on and start executing whatever instructions are at the next addresses.<span class="line"><!---->And so what happens instead is default on Linux so perhaps this is irrelevant).<span class="line"><!---->I think it would happen as well if you try to use WebGPU on any page (that has WebGPU enabled; it's not enabled by default on         Following up on the suspect Windows crash noted in <span class="line"><!---->Following up on the suspect Windows crash noted in <!----></span>#c4<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c4"><!---->#c4<!----></a> and #27:<span class="line"><!----> and #27:<!----></span><br>Seems like the crash I was seeing on Windows was due to the same cause. I never got an OOB on Windows ASan, but still got crashes that started on/after 1054452 and stopped reproducing after 10733161 (which includes patch from <span class="line"><!---->Seems like the crash I was seeing on Windows was due to the same cause. I never got an OOB on Windows ASan, but still got crashes that started on/after 1054452 and stopped reproducing after 10733161 (which includes patch from <!----></span>#c23<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c23"><!---->#c23<!----></a>/<span class="line"><!---->/<!----></span>#c24<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c24"><!---->#c24<!----></a>). Also verified with Canary: crashes on 110.0.5425.0 Canary (unpatched), fixed on 110.0.5426.0 Canary (patched).<span class="line"><!---->). Also verified with Canary: crashes on 110.0.5425.0 Canary (unpatched), fixed on 110.0.5426.0 Canary (patched).<!----></span><br><br>Also lines up with <span class="line"><!---->Also lines up with <!----></span>#c4<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c4"><!---->#c4<!----></a> that indicated repro started in M108, which <span class="line"><!----> that indicated repro started in M108, which <!----></span>#c28<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c28"><!---->#c28<!----></a> indicated was the first version with UNREACHABLE code.<span class="line"><!----> indicated was the first version with UNREACHABLE code.<!----></span><br><br>Not sure if this would also result in memory issues in Windows under other conditions, but at minimum caused stability issues there in my environment.<span class="line"><!---->Not sure if this would also result in memory issues in Windows under other conditions, but at minimum caused stability issues there in my environment.<!----></span><br>Someone else would need to test other OSes to see the behavior there (whether it crashes or causes memory issue).<span class="line"><!---->Someone else would need to test other OSes to see the behavior there (whether it crashes or causes memory issue).<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Thank you for this report and your efforts, Vitor and Alesandro. In evaluating this issue, we don't see any demonstrable evidence of the OOB read. The fix itself is purely a functional fix and we aren't able to see how this is could be exploited. If you can provide some sort of evidence demonstrating the OOB memory access, such as a symbolized stack trace, we would be happy to reassess, but for now we are unable to extend a reward for this report.<span class="line"><!---->Thank you for this report and your efforts, Vitor and Alesandro. In evaluating this issue, we don't see any demonstrable evidence of the OOB read. The fix itself is purely a functional fix and we aren't able to see how this is could be exploited. If you can provide some sort of evidence demonstrating the OOB memory access, such as a symbolized stack trace, we would be happy to reassess, but for now we are unable to extend a reward for this report.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          margin-bottom: 0.75em;
        }
      </style>
      
      
    <!----></mr-launch-overview>
            </div>
          </div>

      VERSION<b class="line"><!---->VERSION<!----></b><br><br>Chrome Version: 105<span class="line"><!---->Chrome Version: 105<!----></span><br>Operating System: Ubuntu 20.04<span class="line"><!---->Operating System: Ubuntu 20.04<!----></span><br><br>VULNERABILITY DETAILS<b class="line"><!---->VULNERABILITY DETAILS<!----></b><br><br>It gets an unknown crash with READ of size 8 when first accessing the chrome://gpu URL with a chrome extension<span class="line"><!---->It gets an unknown crash with READ of size 8 when first accessing the chrome://gpu URL with a chrome extension<!----></span><br><br>REPRODUCTION CASE<b class="line"><!---->REPRODUCTION CASE<!----></b><br><br>== background.js<span class="line"><!---->== background.js<!----></span><br><br>chrome.windows.create({ url: 'about:blank' }, (win) => {<span class="line"><!---->chrome.windows.create({ url: 'about:blank' }, (win) =&gt; {<!----></span><br>    chrome.tabs.update(win.tabs[0].id, { url: 'chrome://gpu' });<span class="line"><!---->    chrome.tabs.update(win.tabs[0].id, { url: 'chrome://gpu' });<!----></span><br>});<span class="line"><!---->});<!----></span><br><br>It seems to consistently crash the GPU process on any first navigation to chrome://gpu<span class="line"><!---->It seems to consistently crash the GPU process on any first navigation to chrome://gpu<!----></span><br>I think it's just a weird thing with WebGPU. I can repro on Canary and Dev which have WebGPU enabled on my machine, but can't repro on Beta which has WebGPU disabled by default<span class="line"><!---->I think it's just a weird thing with WebGPU. I can repro on Canary and Dev which have WebGPU enabled on my machine, but can't repro on Beta which has WebGPU disabled by default<!----></span><br><br>REQUEST FOR CC:<span class="line"><!---->REQUEST FOR CC:<!----></span><br><br>Please CC <span class="line"><!---->Please CC <!----></span>alesandro@alesandroortiz.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="/u/alesandro@alesandroortiz.com"><!---->alesandro@alesandroortiz.com<!----></a> here in this report if this report go forward. He's mentoring me.<span class="line"><!----> here in this report if this report go forward. He's mentoring me.<!----></span><br><br>CREDIT INFORMATION<b class="line"><!---->CREDIT INFORMATION<!----></b><br><br>Vitor Torres <<span class="line"><!---->Vitor Torres &lt;<!----></span>https://github.com/vtorres/<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://github.com/vtorres/"><!---->https://github.com/vtorres/<!----></a>><span class="line"><!---->&gt;<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Thanks for the report!<span class="line"><!---->Thanks for the report!<!----></span><br><br>It'd help us a lot if you could attach all of the files needed for the reproduction (i.e. the extension manifest, etc.). It'd also help a lot if you could work on providing a *symbolized* stack trace.<span class="line"><!---->It'd help us a lot if you could attach all of the files needed for the reproduction (i.e. the extension manifest, etc.). It'd also help a lot if you could work on providing a *symbolized* stack trace.<!----></span><br><br>I can't reproduce this without the extension, and if that's all the extension is doing, I'd be pretty surprised if this impacted real users. Extensions have extremely limited capabilities on chrome:// URLs (including an inability to open them at all).<span class="line"><!---->I can't reproduce this without the extension, and if that's all the extension is doing, I'd be pretty surprised if this impacted real users. Extensions have extremely limited capabilities on chrome:// URLs (including an inability to open them at all).<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        On my Windows machine (Windows 10 Version 21H2 (Build 19044.2006)) , this repros on ASan build 1058972 + 108.0.5355.0 Dev + 109.0.5364.0 Canary, but doesn't repro on 107.0.5304.36 Beta nor 106.0.5249.119 Stable.<span class="line"><!---->On my Windows machine (Windows 10 Version 21H2 (Build 19044.2006)) , this repros on ASan build 1058972 + 108.0.5355.0 Dev + 109.0.5364.0 Canary, but doesn't repro on 107.0.5304.36 Beta nor 106.0.5249.119 Stable.<!----></span><br><br>I'm able to reproduce this on Windows simply by going to chrome://gpu after loading a fresh browser instance, but only get the following from ASan:<span class="line"><!---->I'm able to reproduce this on Windows simply by going to chrome://gpu after loading a fresh browser instance, but only get the following from ASan:<!----></span><br>[7584:10084:1017/194641.304:ERROR:gpu_process_host.cc(990)] GPU process exited unexpectedly: exit_code=1<span class="line"><!---->[7584:10084:1017/194641.304:ERROR:gpu_process_host.cc(990)] GPU process exited unexpectedly: exit_code=1<!----></span><br><br>When this occurs, the Chrome window is mostly black as well for a few seconds (typical of a GPU process crash).<span class="line"><!---->When this occurs, the Chrome window is mostly black as well for a few seconds (typical of a GPU process crash).<!----></span><br><br>If you try navigating to chrome://gpu after a repro, it won't repro until you restart the browser instance again.<span class="line"><!---->If you try navigating to chrome://gpu after a repro, it won't repro until you restart the browser instance again.<!----></span><br><br>I'm actually not certain if this is related to WebGPU, because now my Canary instance shows WebGPU as disabled but it still repros there. (A couple of days there seemed to be a correlation between WebGPU being enabled and the crash.)<span class="line"><!---->I'm actually not certain if this is related to WebGPU, because now my Canary instance shows WebGPU as disabled but it still repros there. (A couple of days there seemed to be a correlation between WebGPU being enabled and the crash.)<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        It can be triggered by an extension (or anything else) opening chrome://gpu for the first time since browser was opened, so only apparent prerequisites are installing a malicious extension and that chrome://gpu hasn't been opened since browser was opened (it's very likely this is met or could be met in the near future since extensions can try again when browser is restarted).<span class="line"><!---->It can be triggered by an extension (or anything else) opening chrome://gpu for the first time since browser was opened, so only apparent prerequisites are installing a malicious extension and that chrome://gpu hasn't been opened since browser was opened (it's very likely this is met or could be met in the near future since extensions can try again when browser is restarted).<!----></span><br><br>Since it's still being analyzed, there's a chance this is only a stability issue, right? Or is it confirmed to be a security issue?<span class="line"><!---->Since it's still being analyzed, there's a chance this is only a stability issue, right? Or is it confirmed to be a security issue?<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

happening without looking at the assembly, but it could be that the compiler assumes it'll never reach this code, so it doesn't even emit the code to return from the function.<!----></span><br>And so           Comment 30<a class="comment-link" href="?id=1375131#c30">Comment 30<!----></a>

        Following up on the suspect Windows crash noted in <span class="line"><!---->Following up on the suspect Windows crash noted in <!----></span>#c4<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c4"><!---->#c4<!----></a> and #27:<span class="line"><!----> and #27:<!----></span><br>Seems like the crash I was seeing on Windows was due to the same cause. I never got an OOB on Windows ASan, but still got crashes that started on/after 1054452 and stopped reproducing after 10733161 (which includes patch from <span class="line"><!---->Seems like the crash I was seeing on Windows was due to the same cause. I never got an OOB on Windows ASan, but still got crashes that started on/after 1054452 and stopped reproducing after 10733161 (which includes patch from <!----></span>#c23<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c23"><!---->#c23<!----></a>/<span class="line"><!---->/<!----></span>#c24<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c24"><!---->#c24<!----></a>). Also verified with Canary: crashes on 110.0.5425.0 Canary (unpatched), fixed on 110.0.5426.0 Canary (patched).<!----></span><br><br>Also lines up with <span class="line"><!---->Also lines up with <!----></span>#c4<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c4"><!---->#c4<!----></a> that indicated repro started in M108, which <span class="line"><!----> that indicated repro started in M108, which <!----></span>#c28<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c28"><!---->#c28<!----></a> indicated was the first version with UNREACHABLE code.<span class="line"><!----> indicated was the first version with UNREACHABLE code.<!----></span><br><br>Not sure if this would also result in memory issues in Windows under other conditions, but at minimum caused stability issues there in my environment.<span class="line"><!---->Not sure if this would also result in memory issues in Windows under other conditions, but at minimum caused stability issues there in my environment.<!----></span><br>Someone else would need to test other OSes to see the behavior there (whether it crashes or causes memory issue).<span class="line"><!---->Someone else would need to test other OSes to see the behavior there (whether it crashes or causes memory issue).<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Thank you for this report and your efforts, Vitor and Alesandro. In evaluating this issue, we don't see any demonstrable evidence of the OOB read. The fix itself is purely a functional fix and we aren't able to see how this is could be exploited. If you can provide some sort of evidence demonstrating the OOB memory access, such as a symbolized stack trace, we would be happy to reassess, but for now we are unable to extend a reward for this report.<span class="line"><!---->Thank you for this report and your efforts, Vitor and Alesandro. In evaluating this issue, we don't see any demonstrable evidence of the OOB read. The fix itself is purely a functional fix and we aren't able to see how this is could be exploited. If you can provide some sort of evidence demonstrating the OOB memory access, such as a symbolized stack trace, we would be happy to reassess, but for now we are unable to extend a reward for this report.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

      VERSION<b class="line"><!---->VERSION<!----></b><br><br>Chrome Version: 105<span class="line"><!---->Chrome Version: 105<!----></span><br>Operating System: Ubuntu 20.04<span class="line"><!---->Operating System: Ubuntu 20.04<!----></span><br><br>VULNERABILITY DETAILS<b class="line"><!---->VULNERABILITY DETAILS<!----></b><br><br>It gets an unknown crash with READ of size 8 when first accessing the chrome://gpu URL with a chrome extension<span class="line"><!---->It gets an unknown crash with READ of size 8 when first accessing the chrome://gpu URL with a chrome extension<!----></span><br><br>REPRODUCTION CASE<b class="line"><!---->REPRODUCTION CASE<!----></b><br><br>== background.js<span class="line"><!---->== background.js<!----></span><br><br>chrome.windows.create({ url: 'about:blank' }, (win) => {<span class="line"><!---->chrome.windows.create({ url: 'about:blank' }, (win) =&gt; {<!----></span><br>    chrome.tabs.update(win.tabs[0].id, { url: 'chrome://gpu' });<span class="line"><!---->    chrome.tabs.update(win.tabs[0].id, { url: 'chrome://gpu' });<!----></span><br>});<span class="line"><!---->});<!----></span><br><br>It seems to consistently crash the GPU process on any first navigation to chrome://gpu<span class="line"><!---->It seems to consistently crash the GPU process on any first navigation to chrome://gpu<!----></span><br>I think it's just a weird thing with WebGPU. I can repro on Canary and Dev which have WebGPU enabled on my machine, but can't repro on Beta which has WebGPU disabled by default<span class="line"><!---->I think it's just a weird thing with WebGPU. I can repro on Canary and Dev which have WebGPU enabled on my machine, but can't repro on Beta which has WebGPU disabled by default<!----></span><br><br>REQUEST FOR CC:<span class="line"><!---->REQUEST FOR CC:<!----></span><br><br>Please CC <span class="line"><!---->Please CC <!----></span>alesandro@alesandroortiz.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="/u/alesandro@alesandroortiz.com"><!---->alesandro@alesandroortiz.com<!----></a> here in this report if this report go forward. He's mentoring me.<span class="line"><!----> here in this report if this report go forward. He's mentoring me.<!----></span><br><br>CREDIT INFORMATION<b class="line"><!---->CREDIT INFORMATION<!----></b><br><br>Vitor Torres <<span class="line"><!---->Vitor Torres &lt;<!----></span>https://github.com/vtorres/<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://github.com/vtorres/"><!---->https://github.com/vtorres/<!----></a>><span class="line"><!---->&gt;<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Thanks for the report!<span class="line"><!---->Thanks for the report!<!----></span><br><br>It'd help us a lot if you could attach all of the files needed for the reproduction (i.e. the extension manifest, etc.). It'd also help a lot if you could work on providing a *symbolized* stack trace.<span class="line"><!---->It'd help us a lot if you could attach all of the files needed for the reproduction (i.e. the extension manifest, etc.). It'd also help a lot if you could work on providing a *symbolized* stack trace.<!----></span><br><br>I can't reproduce this without the extension, and if that's all the extension is doing, I'd be pretty surprised if this impacted real users. Extensions have extremely limited capabilities on chrome:// URLs (including an inability to open them at all).<span class="line"><!---->I can't reproduce this without the extension, and if that's all the extension is doing, I'd be pretty surprised if this impacted real users. Extensions have extremely limited capabilities on chrome:// URLs (including an inability to open them at all).<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        On my Windows machine (Windows 10 Version 21H2 (Build 19044.2006)) , this repros on ASan build 1058972 + 108.0.5355.0 Dev + 109.0.5364.0 Canary, but doesn't repro on 107.0.5304.36 Beta nor 106.0.5249.119 Stable.<span class="line"><!---->On my Windows machine (Windows 10 Version 21H2 (Build 19044.2006)) , this repros on ASan build 1058972 + 108.0.5355.0 Dev + 109.0.5364.0 Canary, but doesn't repro on 107.0.5304.36 Beta nor 106.0.5249.119 Stable.<!----></span><br><br>I'm able to reproduce this on Windows simply by going to chrome://gpu after loading a fresh browser instance, but only get the following from ASan:<span class="line"><!---->I'm able to reproduce this on Windows simply by going to chrome://gpu after loading a fresh browser instance, but only get the following from ASan:<!----></span><br>[7584:10084:1017/194641.304:ERROR:gpu_process_host.cc(990)] GPU process exited unexpectedly: exit_code=1<span class="line"><!---->[7584:10084:1017/194641.304:ERROR:gpu_process_host.cc(990)] GPU process exited unexpectedly: exit_code=1<!----></span><br><br>When this occurs, the Chrome window is mostly black as well for a few seconds (typical of a GPU process crash).<span class="line"><!---->When this occurs, the Chrome window is mostly black as well for a few seconds (typical of a GPU process crash).<!----></span><br><br>If you try navigating to chrome://gpu after a repro, it won't repro until you restart the browser instance again.<span class="line"><!---->If you try navigating to chrome://gpu after a repro, it won't repro until you restart the browser instance again.<!----></span><br><br>I'm actually not certain if this is related to WebGPU, because now my Canary instance shows WebGPU as disabled but it still repros there. (A couple of days there seemed to be a correlation between WebGPU being enabled and the crash.)<span class="line"><!---->I'm actually not certain if this is related to WebGPU, because now my Canary instance shows WebGPU as disabled but it still repros there. (A couple of days there seemed to be a correlation between WebGPU being enabled and the crash.)<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        This seems to be a GPU process crash. It's unclear whether this can be triggered by a remote attacker, but I'm provisionally assigning severity high.           Comment 12<a class="comment-link" href="?id=1375131#c12">Comment 12<!----></a>

          
        by
        
      <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons" rel="stylesheet">
      schedule<i id="availability-icon" class="material-icons inline-icon ${user.last_visit_timestamp ? '': 'inline-icon-unseen'}" title="undefined" hidden="">schedule</i>
      alesa...@alesandroortiz.com<a id="user-link" href="/u/2051716833" title="alesa...@alesandroortiz.com"><!---->alesa...@alesandroortiz.com<!----></a>
      alesa...@alesandroortiz.com<span id="user-text" hidden=""><!---->alesa...@alesandroortiz.com<!----></span>
      <div id="availability-text" class="availability-notice" title="undefined" hidden=""><!----><!----></div>
    <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        
      Thu, Nov 3, 2022, 10:01 AM EDT
    <chops-timestamp title="Thu, Nov 3, 2022, 10:01 AM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1375131#c12">Comment 12<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Thu, Nov 3, 2022, 10:01 AM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1375131#c12">Comment 12<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Thu, Nov 3, 2022, 10:01 AM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        It can be triggered by an extension (or anything else) opening chrome://gpu for the first time since browser was opened, so only apparent prerequisites are installing a malicious extension and that chrome://gpu hasn't been opened since browser was opened (it's very likely this is met or could be met in the near future since extensions can try again when browser is restarted).<span class="line"><!---->It can be triggered by an extension (or anything else) opening chrome://gpu for the first time since browser was opened, so only apparent prerequisites are installing a malicious extension and that chrome://gpu hasn't been opened since browser was opened (it's very likely this is met or could be met in the near future since extensions can try again when browser is restarted).<!----></span><br><br>Since it's still being analyzed, there's a chance this is only a stability issue, right? Or is it confirmed to be a security issue?<span class="line"><!---->Since it's still being analyzed, there's a chance this is only a stability issue, right? Or is it confirmed to be a security issue?<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>
      </div>
    
      
    <mr-comment headinglevel="2"></mr-comment>

is a macro for __builtin_unreachable()<span class="line"><!---->UNREACHABLE is a macro for __builtin_unreachable()<!----></span><br>hard to say exactly what is happening without looking at the assembly, but it could be that the compiler assumes it'll never reach this code, so it doesn't even emit the code to return from the function.<span class="line"><!---->hard to say exactly what is happening without looking at the assembly, but it could be that the compiler assumes it'll never reach this code, so it doesn't even emit the code to return from the function.<!----></span><br>And so what happens instead is that when running code, the process will just go on and start executing whatever instructions are at the next addresses.<span class="line"><!---->And so what happens instead is default on Linux so perhaps this is irrelevant).<span class="line"><!---->I think it would happen as well if you try to use WebGPU on any page (that has WebGPU enabled; it's not enabled by default on         The following revision refers to this bug:<span class="line"><!---->The following revision refers to this bug:<!----></span><br>  <span class="line"><!---->  <!----></span>https://dawn.googlesource.com/dawn/+/b097bf2e341cb96d1d5cf4cede9405d94de3023c<a class="undefined" target="_blank" class="line"><!---->commit <!----></span>b097bf2e341cb96d1d5cf4cede9405d94de3023c<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://crrev.com/b097bf2e341cb96d1d5cf4cede9405d94de3023c"><!---->b097bf2e341cb96d1d5cf4cede9405d94de3023c<!----></a><br>Author: Austin Eng <<span class="line"><!---->Author: Austin Eng         Thank you for this report and your efforts, Vitor and Alesandro. In evaluating this issue, we don't see any demonstrable evidence of the OOB read. The fix itself is purely a functional fix and we aren't able to see how this is could be exploited. If you can provide some sort of evidence demonstrating the OOB memory access, such as a symbolized stack trace, we would be happy to reassess, but for now we are unable to extend a reward for this report.<span class="line"><!---->Thank you for this report and your efforts, Vitor and Alesandro. In evaluating this issue, we don't see any demonstrable evidence of the OOB read. The fix itself is purely a functional fix and we aren't able to see how this is could be exploited. If you can provide some sort of evidence demonstrating the OOB memory access, such as a symbolized stack trace, we would be happy to reassess, but for now we are unable to extend a reward for this report.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

      VERSION<b class="line"><!---->VERSION<!----></b><br><br>Chrome Version: 105<span class="line"><!---->Chrome Version: 105<!----></span><br>Operating System: Ubuntu 20.04<span class="line"><!---->Operating System: Ubuntu 20.04<!----></span><br><br>VULNERABILITY DETAILS<b class="line"><!---->VULNERABILITY DETAILS<!----></b><br><br>It gets an unknown crash with READ of size 8 when first accessing the chrome://gpu URL with a chrome extension<span class="line"><!---->It gets an unknown crash with READ of size 8 when first accessing the chrome://gpu URL with a chrome extension<!----></span><br><br>REPRODUCTION CASE<b class="line"><!---->REPRODUCTION CASE<!----></b><br><br>== background.js<span class="line"><!---->== background.js<!----></span><br><br>chrome.windows.create({ url: 'about:blank' }, (win) => {<span class="line"><!---->chrome.windows.create({ url: 'about:blank' }, (win) =&gt; {<!----></span><br>    chrome.tabs.update(win.tabs[0].id, { url: 'chrome://gpu' });<span class="line"><!---->    chrome.tabs.update(win.tabs[0].id, { url: 'chrome://gpu' });<!----></span><br>});<span class="line"><!---->});<!----></span><br><br>It seems to consistently crash the GPU process on any first navigation to chrome://gpu<span class="line"><!---->It seems to consistently crash the GPU process on any first navigation to chrome://gpu<!----></span><br>I think it's just a weird thing with WebGPU. I can repro on Canary and Dev which have WebGPU enabled on my machine, but can't repro on Beta which has WebGPU disabled by default<span class="line"><!---->I think it's just a weird thing with WebGPU. I can repro on Canary and Dev which have WebGPU enabled on my machine, but can't repro on Beta which has WebGPU disabled by default<!----></span><br><br>REQUEST FOR CC:<span class="line"><!---->REQUEST FOR CC:<!----></span><br><br>Please CC <span class="line"><!---->Please CC <!----></span>alesandro@alesandroortiz.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="/u/alesandro@alesandroortiz.com"><!---->alesandro@alesandroortiz.com<!----></a> here in this report if this report go forward. He's mentoring me.<span class="line"><!----> here in this report if this report go forward. He's mentoring me.<!----></span><br><br>CREDIT INFORMATION<b class="line"><!---->CREDIT INFORMATION<!----></b><br><br>Vitor Torres <<span class="line"><!---->Vitor Torres &lt;<!----></span>https://github.com/vtorres/<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://github.com/vtorres/"><!---->https://github.com/vtorres/<!----></a>><span class="line"><!---->&gt;<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Thanks for the report!<span class="line"><!---->Thanks for the report!<!----></span><br><br>It'd help us a lot if you could attach all of the files needed for the reproduction (i.e. the extension manifest, etc.). It'd also help a lot if you could work on providing a *symbolized* stack trace.<span class="line"><!---->It'd help us a lot if you could attach all of the files needed for the reproduction (i.e. the extension manifest, etc.). It'd also help a lot if you could work on providing a *symbolized* stack trace.<!----></span><br><br>I can't reproduce this without the extension, and if that's all the extension is doing, I'd be pretty surprised if this impacted real users. Extensions have extremely limited capabilities on chrome:// URLs (including an inability to open them at all).<span class="line"><!---->I can't reproduce this without the extension, and if that's all the extension is doing, I'd be pretty surprised if this impacted real users. Extensions have extremely limited capabilities on chrome:// URLs (including an inability to open them at all).<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1375131#c4">Comment 4<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Mon, Oct 17, 2022, 7:53 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>

        On my Windows machine (Windows 10 Version 21H2 (Build 19044.2006)) , this repros on ASan build 1058972 + 108.0.5355.0 Dev + 109.0.5364.0 Canary, but doesn't repro on 107.0.5304.36 Beta nor 106.0.5249.119 Stable.<span class="line"><!---->On my Windows machine (Windows 10 Version 21H2 (Build 19044.2006)) , this repros on ASan build 1058972 + 108.0.5355.0 Dev + 109.0.5364.0 Canary, but doesn't repro on 107.0.5304.36 Beta nor 106.0.5249.119 Stable.<!----></span><br><br>I'm able to reproduce this on Windows simply by going to chrome://gpu after loading a fresh browser instance, but only get the following from ASan:<span class="line"><!---->I'm able to reproduce this on Windows simply by going to chrome://gpu after loading a fresh browser instance, but only get the following from ASan:<!----></span><br>[7584:10084:1017/194641.304:ERROR:gpu_process_host.cc(990)] GPU process exited unexpectedly: exit_code=1<span class="line"><!---->[7584:10084:1017/194641.304:ERROR:gpu_process_host.cc(990)] GPU process exited unexpectedly: exit_code=1<!----></span><br><br>When this occurs, the Chrome window is mostly black as well for a few seconds (typical of a GPU process crash).<span class="line"><!---->When this occurs, the Chrome window is mostly black as well for a few seconds (typical of a GPU process crash).<!----></span><br><br>If you try navigating to chrome://gpu after a repro, it won't repro until you restart the browser instance again.<span class="line"><!---->If you try navigating to chrome://gpu after a repro, it won't repro until you restart the browser instance again.<!----></span><br><br>I'm actually not certain if this is related to WebGPU, because now my Canary instance shows WebGPU as disabled but it still repros there. (A couple of days there seemed to be a correlation between WebGPU being enabled and the crash.)<span class="line"><!---->I'm actually not certain if this is related to WebGPU, because now my Canary instance shows WebGPU as disabled but it still repros there. (A couple of days there seemed to be a correlation between WebGPU being enabled and the crash.)<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        </div>

        This seems to be a GPU process crash. It's unclear whether this can be triggered by a remote attacker, but I'm provisionally assigning severity high. If it can only be triggered locally, please let us know.<span class="line"><!---->This seems to be a GPU process crash. It's unclear whether this can be triggered by a remote attacker, but I'm provisionally assigning severity high. If it can only be triggered locally, please let us know.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        It can be triggered by an extension (or anything else) opening chrome://gpu for the first time since browser was opened, so only apparent prerequisites are installing a malicious extension and that chrome://gpu hasn't been opened since browser was opened (it's very likely this is met or could be met in the near future since extensions can try again when browser is restarted).<span class="line"><!---->It can be triggered by an extension (or anything else) opening chrome://gpu for the first time since browser was opened, so only apparent prerequisites are installing a malicious extension and that chrome://gpu hasn't been opened since browser was opened (it's very likely this is met or could be met in the near future since extensions can try again when browser is restarted).<!----></span><br><br>Since it's still being analyzed, there's a chance this is only a stability issue, right? Or is it confirmed to be a security issue?<span class="line"><!---->Since it's still being analyzed, there's a chance this is only a stability issue, right? Or is it confirmed to be a security issue?<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          Comment 31<a class="comment-link" href="?id=1375131#c31">Comment 31<!----></a>

        Thank you for this report and your efforts, Vitor and Alesandro. In evaluating this issue, we don't see any demonstrable evidence of the OOB read. The fix itself is purely a functional fix and we aren't able to see how this is could be exploited. If you can provide some sort of evidence demonstrating the OOB memory access, such as a symbolized stack trace, we would be happy to reassess, but for now we are unable to extend a reward for this report.<span class="line"><!---->Thank you for this report and your efforts, Vitor and Alesandro. In evaluating this issue, we don't see any demonstrable evidence of the OOB read. The fix itself is purely a functional fix and we aren't able to see how this is could be exploited. If you can provide some sort of evidence demonstrating the OOB memory access, such as a symbolized stack trace, we would be happy to reassess, but for now we are unable to extend a reward for this report.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>

      </div>

           issue<h3 class="medium-heading"><!----> issue</h3>
          
            Target project:<label for="targetProjectInput">Target project:</label>
            
              <input id="targetProjectInput" aria-owns="chops-autocomplete-1" aria-autocomplete="both" aria-expanded="false" aria-haspopup="listbox" aria-activedescendant="">
              
      
        /*
         * Really specific class names are necessary because ShadowDOM
         * is disabled for this component.
         */
        .chops-autocomplete-container {
          position: relative;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container table {
          padding: 0;
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          color: var(--chops-link-color);
          position: absolute;
          background: var(--chops-white);
          border: var(--chops-accessible-border);
          z-index: 999;
          box-shadow: 2px 3px 8px 0px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.3);
          border-spacing: 0;
          border-collapse: collapse;
          /* In the case when the autocomplete extends the
           * height of the viewport, we want to make sure
           * there's spacing. */
          margin-bottom: 1em;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tbody {
          display: block;
          min-width: 100px;
          max-height: 500px;
          overflow: auto;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr {
          cursor: pointer;
          transition: background 0.2s ease-in-out;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr[data-selected] {
          background: var(--chops-active-choice-bg);
          text-decoration: underline;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container td {
          padding: 0.25em 8px;
          white-space: nowrap;
        }
        .screenreader-hidden {
          clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);
          height: 1px;
          overflow: hidden;
          position: absolute;
          white-space: nowrap;
          width: 1px;
        }

          position: relative;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container table {
          padding: 0;
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          color: var(--chops-link-color);
          position: absolute;
          background: var(--chops-white);
          border: var(--chops-accessible-border);
          z-index: 999;
          box-shadow: 2px 3px 8px 0px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.3);
          border-spacing: 0;
          border-collapse: collapse;
          /* In the case when the autocomplete extends the
           * height of the viewport, we want to make sure
           * there's spacing. */
          margin-bottom: 1em;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tbody {
          display: block;
          min-width: 100px;
          max-height: 500px;
          overflow: auto;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr {
          cursor: pointer;
          transition: background 0.2s ease-in-out;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr[data-selected] {
          background: var(--chops-active-choice-bg);
          text-decoration: underline;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container td {
          padding: 0.25em 8px;
          white-space: nowrap;
        }
        .screenreader-hidden {
          clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);
          height: 1px;
          overflow: hidden;
          position: absolute;
          white-space: nowrap;
          width: 1px;
        }
      </style>
      <div class="chops-autocomplete-container">
        <span class="screenreader-hidden" aria-live="polite">
          
        </span>
        <table hidden="">
          <tbody>
            
          </tbody>
        </table>
      </div>
    <!----></mr-autocomplete>
            </div>
          </div>

        <slot></slot>
      </button>

       Note: Avoiding 2-way data binding to futureproof this code
        for LitElement.

 runOnLoad(function() {
 if (typeof(ClientLogger) === "function") {
 let cl = new ClientLogger("issues");
 if (cl.started("new-issue")) {
 cl.logEnd("new-issue", null, 120 * 1000);
 }
 if (cl.started("issue-search")) {
 cl.logEnd("issue-search");
 }
 }
 });
<script type="text/javascript" nonce="">
 runOnLoad(function() {
 if (typeof(ClientLogger) === "function") {
 let cl = new ClientLogger("issues");
 if (cl.started("new-issue")) {
 cl.logEnd("new-issue", null, 120 * 1000);
 }
 if (cl.started("issue-search")) {
 cl.logEnd("issue-search");
 }
 }
 });
</script>
